episodes.summary: Ted brings this case against his father Paul, who has become obsessed with cows.  Ted argues that his father's cow collection and his inclination to randomly say the word cow, among other issues, indicate the need to tamp down the cow-talk.  Paul argues that his obsession is merited, because "cows are our most important animal friends."

episodes.title: Garbage Man and Wife
episodes.summary: Matt Haughey of Metafilter and his wife Kay split household chores right down the middle, except when it comes to garbage duty.  Does the person taking out the trash have "garbage hands" that are only suitable to replace the trash bag and deal with all matters dirty?  Judge John Hodgman decides!

episodes.title: Ob-Law-Di, Ob-Law-Da
episodes.summary: Pat and Joe come before the court with a case about that famous rock band, The Beatles. Pat claims that The White Album is one of The Beatles' worst albums and has a scattered approach. Joe argues that the album benefits from its variance and is one of their best works.

episodes.title: Justice is Out There
episodes.summary: Randi and Chris were gifted Mulder and Scully action figures for Christmas, but differ on their purpose. Should they be kept in their original packaging, to retain value (and for laughs)? Or should they be freed, to re-enact X-Files episodes and general playtime?

episodes.title: The Battle of the Baton
episodes.summary: When Jake listens to his favorite classical music, he finds himself conducting furiously and with abandon.  His wife Erica, an accomplished concert musician, says his flamboyant conducting makes a mockery of her life's work. Must Jake cease his carefree conducting style?

episodes.title: The Friendship Inquest
episodes.summary: Friends Adam and Will have a dispute about social networking.  Is it Adam's responsibility as a young adult to get with the program and join the online social networking world, or is Will pushing his own life choices on his friend?

episodes.title: The Toot Dispute
episodes.summary: Jason's mom argues that whenever he passes gas, he should proffer an "excuse me" to whomever is present (according to general social etiquette).  Jason says he's an adult and as such, is allowed to do as he pleases.  Should Jason's mom butt out, or should be held to her standards?

episodes.title: The Girlfriend and the Grasshopper
episodes.summary: Jeff says his live-in girlfriend Courtney habitually hides food from him. Courtney admits that she's hidden food in the past, but only to save Jeff from his own ravenous tendencies, and that she has stopped the practice. Is Courtney a food-hoarder, or is Jeff a food-stealer?

episodes.title: The Bedroom Three-way
episodes.summary: College pals Corey, Tyler and Caitlyn are moving into a new apartment in the coming school year with three bedrooms: two small, one gloriously spacious. Who deserves the biggest room?

episodes.title: Arby's-tration
episodes.summary: Is it appropriate to ask a cab driver to take you through a drive-thru after a long night of drinking? Take a ride in the Justice Cab to find out.

episodes.title: Tips, Tricks and Justice
episodes.summary: In this episode, we are joined by SPECIAL GUEST and EXPERT WITNESS Morgan Webb.  John argues that using a strategy guide when playing a video game is cheating, pure and simple.  His friend Josef argues that while it provides an advantage, it's not out of line to use a guide and constitutes no cheating.

episodes.title: You Say Tomato, I Say Justice
episodes.summary: We have a pronunciation problem. Matt brings the case against his friend Josh, who he argues pronounces a number of words incorrectly. Affectations, shibboleths, and regionalisms: we've got it all.

episodes.title: An Appeel-ate Case Decision
episodes.summary: Friends (and Canadian barristers) Nick and Phil bring their fruit-based case before the Judge: which gentleman's technique for peeling a banana is correct?

episodes.title: The Ironman Trial-Athlon
episodes.summary: Should an endurance event enthusiast (and former couch potato) be allowed to participate in an Ironman Triathlon against the wishes of his wife?

episodes.title: The Colbert Rapport
episodes.summary: When is it appropriate to request a photo with a celebrity seen in the wild? Andrew and Britt bring this case of a Hollywood party, Stephen Colbert, and potential Facebook popularity before the judge.

episodes.title: Parents Just Don't Understand
episodes.summary: Should a father be able to compell his teenage daughter to watch classic films? Or does a 16-year-old deserve autonomy in her entertainment choices?

episodes.title: The Potluck Problem
episodes.summary: Two best friends disagree on the morality of the potluck. One says it's a great opportunity for everyone to pitch in. One says it's a sign of a host who's abdicated responsibility for the party. Only one man can decide who's right.

episodes.title: Sesame Street Justice
episodes.summary: A group of high school kids kidnapped their youth group leader's life-size Ernie doll as a prank, but he was stolen from them before his safe return.  Can they be held responsible for Ernie's disappearance if they intended to return him?

episodes.title: Snob V. Slob
episodes.summary: A fiancee demands that her sweetheart shape up and dress for a promotion, plus other clothing-related disputes.

episodes.title: The Tahitian Take-Out
episodes.summary: A friends' night out at a Polynesian restaurant, several Scorpion bowls and an abandoned bag of takeout are involved in this accusation of impropriety and substandard hygiene.

episodes.title: You Say Martucci, I Say Martucci
episodes.summary: Sisters Carol and Michelle have a disagreement over the pronunciation of their last name, Martucci. Carol believes in the traditional Italian "Mar-too-CHEE" and Michelle thinks it honors their grandfather to pronounce the name in his preferred fashion, "Mar-too-SEE".

episodes.title: The Case of the Youthful Indiscretions
episodes.summary: Brothers Evan and Michael battle it out: as a toddler, Michael stole Evans things, and gave them away at pre-school. Does Evan deserve an apology?

episodes.title: The Cone-tractual Dispute
episodes.summary: The manufacture of a food truck awning leads to a Portland-infused nightmare.

episodes.title: The Parenthetical Petition
episodes.summary: Recorded live on stage at The Talent Show in Brooklyn: a man believes parentheses have no place in fiction. His girlfriend disagrees.

episodes.title: To Tree Or Not To Tree
episodes.summary: A married couple disagrees: when should the Christmas decorations go up? That is the question. Skakespeare.

episodes.title: The Lion's Den
episodes.summary: A married couple disagrees: what is a den?

episodes.title: The Lovely Couple
episodes.summary: A married couple disagrees: is physical attractiveness a component of romantic love?

episodes.title: The Long-Necked Custody Battle
episodes.summary: Best friends bought a robotic giraffe together in Japan. Now, with college (and their cohabitation) over, each wants the other to have it.

episodes.title: Judge Hodgman: Tear Down That Wall
episodes.summary: Foy argues that breaking the fourth wall ruins film and theater.  His friend Matt disagrees.  Only Judge John Hodgman can decide.

episodes.title: Are Machine Guns Robots?
episodes.summary: Two friends dispute whether machine guns are robots.

episodes.title: Dish Soap or Hand Soap?
episodes.summary: Judge Hodgman settles a marital dispute: should the kitchen sink dispense dish soap or hand soap?
